[Chorus]

This chorus marks a split between two different takes of the song spliced together by Beatles' producer, Sir George Henry Martin.

Everything preceding this chorus, and at the beginning of this chorus, is from Take 7 of the recording session. However, starting with the lyric going to, the rest of the final studio version is from Take 26 of the recording session.

Worth noting is that Take 26 is in a higher key and at a faster tempo. In order to make this work, Martin figured out he could slow down Take 26 to make it the same key as Take 7 in order to make the splice as seamless as possible.

Martin recalled why Lennon wanted this splice to happen:

Ever the idealist, and completely without regard for practical problems, John said to me, “I like them both. Why don’t we join them together? You could start with Take 7 and move to Take [26] halfway through to get the grandstand finish.” “Brilliant!” I replied. “There are only two things wrong with that: the takes are in completely different keys, a whole tone apart; and they have wildly different tempos. Other than that, there should be no problem!” John smiled at my sarcasm with the tolerance of a grown-up placating a child. “Well, George,” he said laconically, “I’m sure you can fix it, can’t you?” whereupon he turned on his heel and walked away.
[Verse 2]

The distinctive instrument that is strummed before each verse is a swarmandal, a type of Indian harp. Just before the second verse, an audible mistake can be heard followed by a rattle and some laughter, suggesting Harrison dropped the plectrum into the sound hole.
Let me take you down,

Lennon will serve as our spirit guide on this journey–into memory? into a trippy hallucinogenic landscape? into the world of the unreal?

As Michael Lewis and Stephen J. Spignesi note in 100 Best Beatles Songs: A Passionate Fan’s Guide (2009):

John’s original opening line for the song was “Let me take you back,” not “Let me take you down.” (His acoustic demo of the song can be heard on Anthology 2.)

https://youtu.be/50JhY-UIuwQ?t=1m6s

The original “let me take you back” most likely referred to his childhood, when he often visited the Salvation Army’s children’s home ‘Strawberrry Field’ for the summer garden parties with his aunt Mimi.
That is I think it’s not too bad

“That is” represents the tune John is singing. He’s saying he’s different from all the others, but maybe that is not “too bad”, also referring to the song itself, cause in the end, that’s why the fans loved him, for being different.

The line is about feeling ambivalent, or conflicted, much like ‘count me out, in’ from Revolution 1. Here though it’s personal and not political – it’s a reflection of the ideal nature of the dreamlike psychological state that Strawberry Feilds, represents.
Strawberry Fields forever

Possibly Lennon calling for childhood to continue forever, or suggesting that it’s a part of us that never dies. A sentiment similar to “Forever Young”–and The Beatles' 1965 release “In My Life”

There are places I’ll remember
All my life, though some have changed…



Gatepost to Strawberry Field, Liverpool. Image via Wikimedia
And nothing to get hung about

To get “hung up about” something means to get overly concerned or uptight about it. If nothing is real, there’s no reason to stress about anything.

This may also be another inside joke about Lennon’s childhood. In The Beatles Lyrics (2014), Hunter Davies explains:

The phrase…suggests not having any hang-ups, but also hanging from a tree possibly, remembering [John’s] Aunt Mimi telling him not to climb over the wall and play there, and John replying, ‘They can’t hang you for it.’
Nothing is real,

This became something of a signature phrase for The Beatles and would be referenced in “Glass Onion”. Ringo Starr would later use it as a mantra when George Harrison admitted he’d been having an affair with Ringo’s then-wife, Maureen Cox.



John is implying that everything is a façade; reality is based on perception and not a concrete, stable thing. The sentiment is associated with the Beatles' LSD phase, and has since been echoed in many other rock lyrics, including the first line of Queen’s “Bohemian Rhapsody”: “Is this the real life? Is this just fantasy?”

Living is easy with eyes closed
 Misunderstanding all you see

Those who “live with eyes closed” willfully misunderstand all they see. Choosing to ignore hard realities is what makes these individuals' lives so easy.

If you live life with your eyes closed, you won’t see anything. Consequently, you’ll misunderstand nothing. And if you never misunderstand anything, then you understand everything and life is easy….right?
Cranberry sauce

John Lennon murmurs this line apropos of nothing in the fade-out. Misheard by many as “I buried Paul,” it lent further credence to the popular conspiracy theory that the real Paul McCartney died in a traffic accident and was replaced by stooges in 1966. Obsessed fans claimed to find further “evidence” in a  wide variety of clues, including secret messages audible when the song is played backward.

The “Paul is dead” conspiracy theory makes this throwaway nonsense line arguably the single most scrutinized song lyric of the 20th century. At the height of the meme, Life magazine ran an entire cover story debunking the myth:

’cause I’m going to
 Strawberry Fields

Strawberry Field (singular) was a recreational ground and a Salvation Army children’s home in Liverpool, England, close to John Lennon’s childhood home.



From Rolling Stone:

“We were trying to write about Liverpool, and I just listed all the nice-sounding names arbitrarily. But I have visions of Strawberry Fields… . Because Strawberry Fields is just anywhere you want to go.”

Lennon spent a lot of his childhood at Strawberry Field.

“As soon as we could hear the Salvation Army band starting, John would jump up and down shouting, ‘Mimi, come on. We’re going to be late.’”
–Mimi Smith (John’s aunt and guardian), quoted in Hunter Davies' The Beatles (1968, p. 9)

The Strawberry Fields memorial in Central Park is dedicated to Lennon and named in honor of this song.

Strawberry is also a street name for LSD.
